question.title: Is it mandatory to specify the data type of a base class which is declared generic while inheriting?
question.body:
I'm trying to understand Java generics better. Suppose I have a generic base class like this:

class Base<T> {
    T data;
}

Now, if I create a subclass, do I need to mention the parameter type for the base class?

Specify the concrete type while extending

class Child extends Base<String> {
    // Uses Base<String>
}

Or I can use like this

class Child extends Base {
    // 
}

Is it mandatory to mention the type parameter when extending a generic class and what happens if I don't specify any type — instead just class Child extends Base?

answers.body:
The only objectively correct answer to your question is "because the spec (the Java Language Specification) says so".

I'm assuming that's not a satisfying answer. However, know that therefore the rest of this answer is somewhat subjective. It's trying to answer why the language is designed this way.

Note, first, that your question has an error in it. What you meant to write is this:

class Child<T> extends Base<T> {
  // keeps it generic
}

Raw types

Java 1.0-1.4 didn't have any generics. Java strongly prefers allowing code written at java version X to compile and run on Y (where Y is higher than X). If that's not the case, say, if java 1.5 which introduced generics means all code written in java 1.4 or below simply fails to compile, then, is it really java 1.5, or is it more fair to call it qava 1.0 - i.e. a completely new language at that point?

The way generics was added to the language, and the way to ensure pre-generics code compiles and runs on post-generics java versions, is the concept Raw types.

Just List is a raw type. If you try to use it, it works, but the compiler throws in the towel and will no longer ensure type safety for you. This compiles and runs, and because it's not actually valid, ends up throwing a ClassCastException even though there is no cast in this code:

List<String> list = new ArrayList<String>();
list.add("Hello");
List raw = list;
List<Number> numbers = raw;
System.out.println(numbers.get(0).intValue()); //CCEx here

The CCEx is fair enough - your string ("Hello") isn't a number, and doesn't have an intValue() method.

But, you could write the above code in java 1.4 just the same (remove < and > and everything in between them), and it would compile and run.. and throw the same ClassCastException (that is, if you add a cast to Number to numbers.get(0), of course).

Reason number 1: If class Ext extends Base means "Ext also has a <T> just like Base does", then.. how would I extend Ext with the intent that I want to extend the raw type? You wouldn't be able to.

in java 1.4, List is just List. It has no <E>. It can't - generics did not exist at all. Hence, code was out there writing class Foo implements List and the author of this code has no idea about generics. They think add takes any Object and get returns an Object. You cannot silently reinterpret this hypothetical Foo class as having invisible generics and have all possible code one could write that compiled fine on java 1.4 also compile fine in this world. The only way you can do that is with this raw type concept.

Hence, extends Base means 'extend Base (the raw type)' and thus if you want to keep the generics, you have to write class Foo<T> extends Base<T>.

It's semantically correct

I am free to write:

class Base<T extends Serializable> {  }
class Ext<T extends Number> extends Base<T> { .. }

I have redefined the bounds here. This is legal. Hence, what you're proposing/thinking of is a shortcut: If I want to keep the generics and not redefine the bounds, what if we define the language specification that this is what happens when I don't specify these generics at all?

But that's a bit odd then. If you want to keep the generics and keep the same bounds, you write nothing. If you want to keep the generics but change the bounds, you.. write <> all of a sudden. Inconsistent - that's bad in lang design.

Ext has its own generics that lives independent of Base. You have to say that whilst independent, the T of Ext is fulfilling the T of base.

The above points should then answer all your questions:

1.Why is it mandatory to mention the type parameter when extending a generic class?

Two reasons:

  • There needs to be syntax to change the bounds anyway.
  • There needs to be a way to say you want to extend the raw type.

2.What happens if I don't specify any type — instead just class Child extends Base?

You'd get the raw type. Your code compiles and might work, but the compiler will do no type checking on the generics at all, and will emit a warning when you compile explaining that its flying blind and will not give you the usual guarantees about type safety.

  1. Why do I need to declare the child class with Generic if I'm not fixing the type to Base class?

I'm not quite sure I understand, but if that means:

Given A: class Ext extends Base<String>

Given B: class Ext<T> extends Base<T>

Then you mean with 'fixing the type to Base' as 'like A' and 'not fixing the type to Base' as 'like B in contrast to A' - then this boils down to the same question as your first.

question_comments.body: @Chris I have had dozens of questions closed for this reason, so at least two other people agreed with me in each case.
@user207421 see meta.stackoverflow.com/a/417484/354577 and search the page for "lack of effort"
@Crhis I've only been here since 2009 but that's news to me. It seems a perfectly valid close reason to me. The OP could have answered this for himself in 5 minutes, and so could anybody else.
@user207421, that's a reason to downvote, not a reason to close
I’m voting to close this question because it exhibits zero prior research.
What would you expect child.getData() to return?

(1) It's not technically mandatory, as explained by user85421. (2) You get a raw type. See What is a raw type and why shouldn't we use it?. (3) I'm not sure I really understand what you're trying to ask. However, type parameters are not inherited. Even in your second option, the T declared in Child is separate from the T declared in Base; the former is just being used to parameterize the latter when subclassing. If you had class Child extends Base<T> then that would fail to compile because T hasn't be declared anywhere in scope.

it is not (yet) "mandatory" (example class Child extends Base { } - but it is strongly recommended to specify a type - see Java Language Specification 4.8. Raw Types: "The use of raw types in code written after the introduction of generics into the Java programming language is strongly discouraged."
Yes, class Child<T> extends Base<T> and when declaring child as generic is it mandatory to mention Base as generic?
